importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: This is the date of the game in which Shohei Ohtani delivered a historic two-way performance, leading the Dodgers to a 5-1 victory over the Brewers in Game 4 of the NLCS, securing their place in the World Series.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The entire event occurred on a single night, October 18, 2025, marking a decisive moment in the 2025 National League Championship Series, with Ohtani's performance culminating in the Dodgers' sweep and advancement to the World Series.

keyTakeAways: Shohei Ohtani delivered a historic two-way performance in Game 4 of the 2025 NLCS, hitting three home runs and striking out 10 batters while pitching shutout ball into the seventh inning.
The Los Angeles Dodgers swept the Milwaukee Brewers in the NLCS, becoming only the fifth team to sweep a best-of-seven series and the first to do so since 2019.
Ohtani's performance earned him National League Championship Series MVP honors and is considered one of the greatest individual postseason performances in baseball history.

The Dodgers are now headed to the 2025 World Series for the first time in nine seasons and will attempt to become the first team in baseball history to win back-to-back World Series titles since the Yankees in 1998â€“2000.

The Brewers, who led the majors with 97 wins during the regular season, were eliminated for the third time in their seven playoff appearances in eight years, failing to reach their first World Series since 1982.
The Dodgers' four starters combined for 28 2/3 innings, allowing just two earned runs and 35 strikeouts, showcasing dominant pitching depth and control.

Ohtani's first home run as a pitcher in MLB history was a leadoff homer off Jose Quintana in the first inning, followed by a 469-foot home run in the fourth and a third solo shot in the seventh, making him the 12th player to hit three homers in a postseason game.
This performance marks Ohtani's third MVP award and solidifies his status as a defining figure in modern baseball.

namedEntities.name: Shohei Ohtani
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Professional baseball player, two-time MLB MVP, and a two-way player (pitcher and hitter)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Ohtani delivered a historic two-way performance in the NLCS, hitting three home runs and striking out 10, earning NLCS MVP honors and propelling the Dodgers to the World Series.

namedEntities.name: Los Angeles Dodgers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Major League Baseball team based in Los Angeles
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Dodgers swept the Milwaukee Brewers in the NLCS, clinched a spot in the 2025 World Series, and are aiming to become the first team in 25 years to win back-to-back championships.

namedEntities.name: Milwaukee Brewers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Major League Baseball team based in Milwaukee
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Brewers were swept in the NLCS by the Dodgers, marking their third elimination in seven playoff appearances, and failing to advance to the World Series for the first time since 1982.

namedEntities.name: Dave Roberts
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Roberts praised Ohtani's performance as 'the greatest postseason performance of all time' and emphasized the significance of the Dodgers' sweep and advancement to the World Series.

namedEntities.name: Freddie Freeman
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Dodgers player, former World Series MVP
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Freeman commended Ohtani's performance as 'absolutely incredible' and described the moment as 'the biggest stage' for Ohtani to deliver a historic performance.

namedEntities.name: Jose Quintana
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Quintana started the game against Ohtani, who hit a leadoff homer off him, marking the first time a pitcher has hit a leadoff home run in MLB history.

namedEntities.name: Roki Sasaki
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Sasaki pitched a scoreless ninth inning in the NLCS, securing the final out and completing the Dodgers' sweep with a successful relief appearance.

namedEntities.name: Mookie Betts
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Betts and Will Smith contributed runs in the first inning after Ohtani's initial homer, helping the Dodgers build a lead in the game.

namedEntities.name: Blake Perkins
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Perkins acknowledged that the Brewers' offense failed to produce in the NLCS, noting that their bats 'fell silent' against the Dodgers' strong starting rotation.

namedEntities.name: Caleb Durbin
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Durbin scored a run in the eighth inning after Brice Turang reached base, contributing to the Dodgers' final run in the game.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In a historic performance on October 18, 2025, Shohei Ohtani delivered a legendary two-way performance in Game 4 of the National League Championship Series, hitting three home runs and striking out 10 batters while pitching shutout ball into the seventh inning. His first homer off Brewers starter Jose Quintana became the first leadoff home run by a pitcher in MLB history, and his 469-foot blast in the fourth cleared a pavilion roof. The Dodgers used this dominance to sweep the Milwaukee Brewers in the NLCS, becoming only the fifth team to sweep a best-of-seven series and the first since 2019. The victory marks the Dodgers' first postseason sweep in 16 years and advances them to the 2025 World Series for the 23rd time in franchise history. Ohtani was named NLCS MVP, cementing his status as one of the greatest individual postseason performers in baseball history. The Brewers, who led the majors with 97 wins, were eliminated for the third time in seven playoff appearances and have not advanced to the World Series since 1982.
title: Shohei Ohtani hits 3 homers and strikes out 10 in Dodgers' clinching 5-1 NLCS win over Brewers
